comments.commentBody:
"All along the diverse main drag, Hamra Street, fully black veiled Shiite Muslim matrons drift past dolled-up, miniskirted Christian women..."

When are we going to stop reading this lame, cliche sentence in articles about Beirut?! I mean, why is it always a Shiite woman in black and a Christian women in a miniskirt? Why not a Sunni girl in micro-shorts and a conservative Christian matron or a Druze shaykha? and how does a mini skirt tell you its owner's confession? NYTimes should do better than this!

Very nice description of the cultural and economic boom happening in Hamra. However, the article doesn't mention that Hamra has also become a great spot for dining with its many cafes and restaurants. my personal favorite being a new Mexican restaurant next to AUH (El-Molino).
Hamra--so many pre-war memories! Glad to know of its revival. The generation that grew up during the war barely knows it.
thank god it didn't mention captains... no need to encourage more people to go to beirut. but for the uninitiated ;) http://williamcurtisdonovan.com.../

"miniskirted Christian women" : Thanks for spreading the cliche. Although completely veiled women are most probably Shiite, miniskirted ones can be everything. Did you ask each one of them what religion they were? It is really upsetting to see such assumptions made by a newspaper I admire.
Apart from that, LOVE Carafe, and great article!

I watched this episode.  Spitzer seems to be nothing but a silly little man.  I thought he was some really intelligent disgraced former-governor.  How this guy was ever elected to statewide office, anywhere, is a mystery.  Unless this epsidoe was simply a joke, Spitzer can't be taken seriously, and CNN continues the decline
The Left media's coordinated attempt to breathe life into this dead career is disgusting.

pathetic
vast wasteland

It's a taped show with choppy editing, and it appears to be heavily scripted. The best part of the program was the Elizabeth Warren interview, obviously truncated for time. The whole production had a soundbite quality to it.

One misguided choice of a guest was Andrew Breitbart, whose explanation of his Shirley Sherrod edited- tape hit job was so rushed at the very end that I missed it. It was doubletalk, and went totally unchallenged by the hosts. Then there was some kind of party time chatfest at the end of the show, when one guest described his summer of eight cavities and overcoming a Mike & Ike addiction. The frenetic co-mingling of serious and vacuous left me feeling a bit dizzy.

I liked Kathleen Parker during the few moments she was able to get a word in edgewise. I kind of wish she had smacked Eliot over the head with one of newspaper props on their coffee table to get him to shut up. And the guests talking over each other.... somebody at CNN - please offer Larry King his job back!

Just the idea of giving Spitzer an hour every night has convinced me that CNN no longer wants me as a viewer. What's next, an arts and entertainment program hosted by Roman Polanski? Spitzer was caught in the act of sex trafficking across state lines, engaging in prostitution and abusing his office by using the state police to silence his political rivals. Put a fork in him, he's done.
Spitzer is very profligate, (utterly & shamelessly immoral). I wonder how his wife and his kids look upto this man. He just needs to go away.

I am choosing not to watch Spitzer nor CNN since they fired Rick Sanchez. In fact I'm not watching T V at all these days.  I live in Hawaii and I stream KPFK in on my computer. Maybe I'm finished with cable news?

comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody: I won't even bother dignifying the two idiotic comments to this story, but rather I'd say that I wish Vick luck in his continued quest to rehabilitate himself.

cpm - I also liked it a couple of years ago when NHLN showed the entire HNIC program from 6:30 until After Hours. Sometimes now, when the first game ends, you lose that between game programming that leads up to the second game of the double header.

On the other hand, there are so many games on Sat. night that seeing On The Fly once the first game ends is not a terrible alternative.

And, yeah, the commercials are great. Jeez, you even remember the sponsors. What's wrong with you?

Dan from Maryland, you put things perfectly. I wouldn't have agreed before about the manager, but you're right. He has failed to convince this team to play team baseball, and I think that his jittery personality has affected the rest of the team. They all seem to tighten up in the clutch. Clearly the absence of Damon and Matusi accounts for the difference between last year and this year. And that one's on Cashman.
I should be general manager ... I could do this ... what's so hard? Oh, wait ... it won't work ... I'm a Yankee fan
Who?  The Mets?  Are they a baseball team?

Rumor has it good friends Andrew Napolitano and Ralph Nader have contemplated a run in 2012.  Don't know if those rumors are substantiated, but how's that for a political odd couple who could garner some votes from the left and from libertarian leaning right!
the economy will be better by 2012. Voter anger is overplayed. The press needs a story and the pundits take themselves too seriously.

What does a "third party" candidate mean anymore. Half the Republican's running for election to Senate seats were elected by the "Tea Party." These Republicans are far to the right of where the Republican Party was 10 years ago.

Ron Paul ran in the Republican Primary in 2008, as a Libertarian.

Pretty much as a third party candidate you need major name recognition and/or a lot of money. Bloomberg is not the type who would run in a "symbolic race" which it obviously would be for him in 2012, even more so if the economy turned around, or Obama otherwise had an approval rating of at least the mid-50's (55%+). Bloomberg wouldn't enter such a race.

The larger issue is whether the GOP will become a divided party. If Obama turns the country around, and pushes his approval rating to around 60%, the "Tea Party" will still elect the GOP-nominee. In almost every state the Republican Nominee is picked solely by Republican voters as Independents can't vote in the Republican Primary. Since 2008, so many moderate Republicans have become Independents (or Democrats) that the Republican Party has an even higher concentration of conservatives. If Obama turns things around, and his approval rating hovers around 60%, it will be hard for Obama to be picked as an extreme candidate, and many moderate Republicans will break, and with a "Tea Party" candidate, even some conservative candidates will break off. If Obama can show a clear vision for controlling spending, and controlling the national debt, can have passed dynamic policies to control waste and make the government more efficient, Obama might get a serious % of the vote of "fiscal conservatives."

The question should just be how will the third-party candidates affect the race, not whether a third party candidate would be viable.

If someone like Ron Paul ran as a third-party candidate and got just 5% of the vote in the general election on the Libertarian ticket, that would increase Obama's spread over the Republican Party candidate, while also have a very fiscal conservative Republican (Ron Paul) attack the GOP and it's candidates of not being true fiscal conservatives.

In the general election, someone like Ron Paul stealing 5 points from the Republican candidate, even if Obama would win otherwise, that increases his margin, and would depress Republican turnout.

The ideal situation for Obama would be Sarah Palin losing the primary and running as a third-party candidate, as I actually think she could get 10-15% of the General Election vote, especially if the GOP picks someone that is not super super conservative. This would completely screw up the electoral map for the GOP.

Michael Bloomberg I don't see becoming the dynamic candidate Ross Perot does. His self-proclaimed credentials as having this ability to work across party lines, has not been demonstrated outside of New York City politics, he has had no role in Washington, or national policy, other then to lead this "Mayors Against Illegal Guns" group. He is not a strong campaigner, and being an old, rich, white, unmarried, short, Jewish, New Yorker is not something that will help in getting votes in Iowa or Ohio.

Fox News would give no time to this third party candidate even if he is farther to the right, more conservative. They just wouldn't.

The Liberal Democrats (far left) will understand the situation Obama is in (if the Democrats lose House/Senate seats in 2010) and will not accuse Obama of being a conservative if he can't pass the amount of progressive policy they'd iike, and then push for far-left liberal candidate like Ralph Nader. That won't happen. The super-far-right Republicans won't break off and support a Tea Party candidate as that will probably be the GOP nominee.

So where will this third party come from if it is not a party to the right of the GOP or left of the Democratic Party? Someone in the middle, who promises to bring the two parties together? Anyone who understands the GOP strategy understands the GOP is determined to block progressive agenda, will work to defeat any President whether a Democrat or Independent Party President that has a goal to have real reforms. Some third party candidate running in the middle, is running as someone who can bring the two parties together, but who would be able to sell that, if they have never served in national politics, as everyone in the House and Senate is a Democrat or Republican, other than Joe Lieberman-CT and Bernie Sanders-VT, neither of which would get more then 1% of the vote.

There is no room for a third party. The only third party possibility is people fed up that the GOP lost it's way. If Obama can get broad support for his policies, and the GOP tries to block everything, perhaps someone who pitches themself as a true fiscal conservative, some corporate CEO-type person, has somewhat sensical solutions, and is seen as having integrity, that might absorb the Republicans that flee the Tea Party-ruled GOP.

Speculation about Sarah Palin running for president seems so off base to me. It seems much more likely that she is in this for the speaking fees/publishing advances, not running for public office. She'll appear to flirt with running for office for as long as she can milk a few bucks out of it, but she'll never actually subject herself to an actual run for office.

I can't help but notice: the "independents" (Senators Olympia Snowe of Maine, Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, and Ben Nelson of Nebraska) have largely determined policy for the past 2 years. They're the ones Obama has to go to in order to get anything through the Senate. So a "radical center" candidate would need to face the question: how are your policies different from what we have now??

So if there is a viable 3rd party candidate it won't be a radical centrist - it will be a rich egotist.

The assumption that Palin will be the Repbublican nominee is dream for Democrats that will not come true. Most Republicans I talk to like only her straightforwardness but would never vote for her. She gave up the job as Governor of Alaska so she could make money-not run for President. I anticipate the Republicans will put up a much more traditional candidate (like Romney, Huckabee, perhaps a Christie) and run against a fairly weak Obama. It should be a good race but don't expect an independent to waste time or money. Money doesn't buy elections either. Just ask Meg Whitman in California who appears to be going down for the count. Fortunately for her, she will still have plenty of money left.

dopper ->

1. legalize marijuana
2. end the war in afghanistan
3. yes on gay marriage

... OK ... these issues are all to the left of the Democratic Party - but they are also "Libertarian" ... if a Libertarian ran on these issues and "small government" economics... I can imagine such a candidate picking up steam in the conditions that Nate described (an unpopular Obama and an unpopular Republican like Palin)

I am amazed that you are getting posts on here that need to be removed. This place is cerebral. Must be some miscreants from The American Spectator.

Anyhow, while I think Nate has pretty much nailed the analysis of why there are a lot of background conditions perfvect for a 3rd part Presidential candidate, I think he is far too sanguine about the ability of anyone to actually get the necessary traction.

As one said on here, the likelihood of a serious 3rd party bid (this would really be "independent", like Ross Perot, as they would not have any real party behind them) would likely come from the very right (Tea Partier types) who realize that nothing much changes when the Republicans gain control of Congress (or at least the House).

And as another said, the best prospect for a real third party movement gaining traction is through the takeover of an existing party (we may be seeing this, although it will surely take a few election cycles).

The money thing is far too big an impediment to anyone making a serious challenge. Michael Bloomberg is small potatoes (and he seems to be D-inclined anyway -- hence all the rumours of him as the next secretary of the treasury). Having a couple hundred million ain't even close. Obama spent that much. Perot had a couple of billion, and he was kind of crazy. And what did he spend, like $100 million? And that was the equivalent of 4 generations ago int erms of how things have changed.

Friedman spins very nice stories. And he is mostly right in his analysis of what ails our society as far as I am concerned (his books, especially so). But it ain't gonna happen. Why? Most of the posts in here tell the story. The people just aren't up to it. The system has beaten them downs, chewed them up and spit them out. Therre hopes of change have been dashed and destroyed by the perversity and perversion that is the political system. People just want to protect what they have, hope that they can keep it, struggle to make ends meet, and don't have any energy left to battle with the machine anymore.

Until the money that drives the system is taken out of play, America's future prospects are very bleak indeed.
